subsection.name: Introduction
subsection.p: JCR Shell provides a command-line tool to get access to a remote JCR Webdav Server which provides JCR API access over WebDAV/HTTP(S).
JCR Shell is a pure JCR/Jackrabbit based client tool. Therefore, this tool should work against any Apache Jackrabbit based JCR system.

div.p: If you want to use JCR Shell against Hippo CMS, enable JCR Webdav Server in the system. See Hippo Repository JCR/WebDAV Support forge project homepage for detail.

subsection.name: Download
subsection.p: You can download an executable JAR file of JCR Shell from Hippo Forge Maven repository: https://maven.onehippo.com/maven2-forge/org/onehippo/forge/jcrshell/jcrshell/. Move to the latest version directory and download jcrshell-x.x.x.jar from there.

subsection.name: Example Usage Session - Setting a property
subsection.p: In this section, let's try to change a property value and save it, as an example.

div.source:
jcr-shell:> cd /webfiles/site
done. Command completed in 879 msecs.
admin:/webfiles/site> proplist ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name Type Value ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- jcr:primaryType Name webfiles:bundle webfiles:anticache String 1538775596692 ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Command completed in 55 msecs.
admin:/webfiles/site> propset webfiles:anticache 1538775596694 Command completed in 0 msecs.
admin:/webfiles/site> propget webfiles:anticache 1538775596694 Command completed in 25 msecs.
admin:/webfiles/site> save Node saved. Command completed in 31 msecs.
jcr-shell:> quit Bye bye!

subsection.name: Run Batch Commands
subsection.p: You can execute a batch file containing one or multiple lines of each command explained above as well by specifying --batch argument like the following example:
If you specify a batch file by --batch argument, then JCR Shell will read all the non-blank lines from the file except of comment lines.

div.p: If a line in a batch file starts with "#", the line is regarded as a comment.
